participant.affiliation: Deputy Chief Executive Officer & Chief Operating Officer

plist.p: Hello, everybody, and thanks to be with us this morning. We have on stage today Pierre Pringuet, CEO of Pernod Ricard; Alexandre Ricard, newly appointed Deputy CEO and COO; and Gilles Bogaert, our CFO. They will take one hour also to walk you through the presentation, and then there will be time for your questions. Question in English, please, as we will do everything in English today. Thank you very much. Pierre, I hand over to you.

Thank you, Jean. So, that's start of the presentation. But of course, with just a word on Patrick, and I would like to underline the – what he said, we are all passionate creators, and that exactly what we intend to do for the future.
So, the overall analysis, we exceeded our guidance, both on the profit and the indebtedness, plus 9% versus plus 8% – close to 8%. And net debt to EBITDA, 3.8 versus 3.9.

May I just underline that these are the best growth rate since the crisis. And this is the case for our sales, and this is the case also for the profit from recurring operations. Here are the numbers, €8.2 billion for the sales; €2.1 million for the profit from recurring operations. The group share of net profit is €1.2 million plus 10%. We improved our operating margin by 75 basis points, which is a very good achievement. And I won't repeat what I said regarding the indebtedness.

Now, entering into more details for the sales, you can see the split between the organic growth, which is basically the bulk of our growth. The group structure and the ForEx impact just balance each other. But may I underline that for the first time, yes, we start to have a positive ForEx impact, which is good news. And this is basically due to the U.S. dollars, but also to the Chinese renminbi.

If I focus on the Q4, there, you can see that the ForEx impact is very significant, I mean, plus 6%. The organic growth seems to be lower, plus 4%. But in fact, if you restate it from the French destocking, it's in the range of plus 7%, and I will show that to you immediately. So, the first line give you the organic growth for the first half, the Q3, Q4 and, of course, the second half.

But then if you – and the second line, if you restate it from the two technical effects, which were the French destocking, but also the Chinese New Year, you can see that we have achieved 8% organic growth for the first half, and you remember that we presented that to you when we presented the half year result; the Q3 at plus 8%; the Q4 at plus 7% and the full year at plus 8%. That's a running impact.

So, we can see that the growth profile is very evenly spread over the year. I mean, there's not sort of any deceleration at the end of the year as maybe some people could think, so a very evenly spread growth profile over the year.

Then, by region, so for each region, you have the share of the sales for each regions, then the organic growth for the previous year, 2010-2011, and then the organic growth rate for the past year, 2011-2012. So, starting with Asia/Rest of the World, it's the first region of Pernod Ricard now, 39% of our sales, very similar growth, I mean, plus 15%, plus 15%, so we saw continued growth momentum. And I should say driven by premium, super premium, ultra premium and prestige brand, because that's very much where we sell those brands.

The Americas, 26% of our sales. And that is the confirmation of what we told you and then the improvements, plus 6%. And it's even better in the U.S. and this is really the region where we sell our premium and super premium brands.

Europe, excluding France, 26% of our sales. It's an improvement, too. We were flat the previous year, plus 2% last year. And this is very much the acceleration in Eastern Europe, which is offsetting the decline in the West, but it was not very different from the previous year.

France, yes, it's a deterioration. We were positive the previous year, in 2010-2011. We're at minus 1% now. Definitely, this is the impact of the duty hike which we had in January this year. And all in all, you can see that we improved our growth profile from 7% to 8%.

Entering into details now region by region, so Asia/Rest of the World, €3.2 billion of sales, plus 17% year-on-year, organically, plus 15%. Martell is definitely one of the main growth driver, plus 29%. I should probably underline that it's above what is the medium-term growth profile for which we want for Martell, just because of availability, but managing scarcity is always good when you have to sell the sort of brands, so, certainly in term of price. We had the milestone of 1 million cases, which we exceed in China. Just a note of sadness, it was the last event – the celebration of the 1 millionth case was the last event Patrick participated to in the end of July.

The top 14 Scotch whisky, plus 13%. Well, that's volume and premiumizations. Indian whisky, plus 26%, very buoyant. And we had also premiumizations for this local brands with the launch of the Barrel Select for Royal Stag and the Reserve Collection for Blender's Pride. We have the good development of Absolut, champagne and wine. We will show that with more detail. I mean, the champagne is, for instance, buoyant in China and, by the way, we believe that we are the leader. On the other hand, we suffered with local brand, if I can describe it. So, Imperial in Korea minus 6%, 100 Pipers in Thailand and that reflect the difficulty of the market.

Continuing with Asia, so now by country, China, plus 24%. So, I mean, that's an impressive growth above, I would say – what we would say that – the medium-term trends, and , of course, it's Martell, Scotch whiskey, champagne, Jacob's Creek. India, the local whisky, already mentioned that, but I should also stress that the Top 14 posted an impressive plus 33%, and this is Chivas, Absolut and The Glenlivet.

Other emerging markets, obviously, Vietnam, I think we're too shy to show the growth rate, but I think it's absolutely impressive in this market, and also Africa and Middle East, plus 12%. And you know that Africa is a sort of new frontier for Pernod Ricard, because we are in the process of creating five new affiliates in different countries of Africa, because we really believe that potential is there and we need to capture that.

And the Pernod Ricard strategy is, we want to sell our brand with our own people. We need our own people in this continent as well. Taiwan, plus 17%, and this is, of course, driven by the Scotch whisky, Martell and Beefeater.

Travel retail, and the travel retail is the showcase for our luxury brands, plus 23%. I mean, it's – I think premiumization is an understatement for what we achieve in that sort of market. South Korea, minus 2%, but it's on the one hand, another decline which we had with Imperial, minus 6%. And you can see that on the contrary, the Top 14 brands at plus 6% are doing pretty well. And this is reflecting the evolution of the market in Korea. The traditional on-trade is declining, and I think it's structural. On the contrary, the modern on-trade is absolutely buoyant, and that's what we enter with our top 14.
Thailand's minus 4%. Again, that's the decline of 100 Pipers. On the other hand, the top 14 is just thriving, plus 14% (10:12) by chance.

Japan. We're very, very pleased with Japan, plus 8%. It's driven by many of our brands. We mentioned two, the Café de Paris, and this is innovation. There's a continuous pipeline of new flavors and – regarding with Café de Paris and that's a very good achievement and well managed by our French affiliate, Pernod, who is the producer or the brand owner of Café de Paris and Pernod Ricard Japan. And Perrier-Jouët. Perrier-Jouët, when we took over the brand from the huge Suntory, we did better. And today, Japan is in value – the very – the top market for the brand.

And Australia, that's a very good performance as well at plus 7%, and Mumm particularly was very good. And the premium wines, they are doing well, plus 8%. So it's definitely a turnaround compared to the year before.

The Americas, so plus 6% organically. The top 14 is, in fact, at plus 5%, but if you exclude Mexico, and I will come back to that later on, plus 7%. So this is definitely Jameson, Malibu, The Glenlivet, Perrier-Jouët, Absolut, Ballantine's, so that's really the – what's the driving force for our growth in this continent.

The Priority Premium Wines, at plus 12%, and it's a very good performance including internal profit. The key local brands, plus 8%, and I would particularly mention Passport which we launched in, for instance, in Brazil, in Mexico. And this is, clearly, we – the intention to have a standard Scotch whisky offering to conquer the middle class because that's this middle class, what is emerging and developing fast. And I think we have the right tool with Passport to conquer it.

Now, looking at the United States, in particular. So you remember that when I presented the first half, we said that it was the very good news of the year and it continued to be the very good news of the year. The U.S. are firmly established in the recovery. And what is entrusting is that the on-trade is definitely reflecting the turnaround in this market.

So Absolut improved the performance in the second half. The first half was slightly negative. The second half is definitely positive and you can see that, on the full year basis, we are positive and we are very confident that the momentum, with all the new initiatives which we've taken, will continue to strengthen the growth profile of Absolut.
Jameson, plus 29%. I'm sorry to repeat that sort of number year-on-year. Despite the crisis, we have been constantly between 25% and 30%. The brand is just flying.

Malibu, plus 10%. And this is very much the innovation pipeline which we developed for the brand with the cocktails, with the Malibu Black which is almost a rum with a 35% alcohol, the Malibu Red, all very well received by the market. Glenlivet, plus 9%, and I should also mention that the higher grade, I mean the 18-year-old of Glenlivet, which retail for $80 a bottle, plus 26%. I mean, that's an extraordinary performance. I remind you that Glenlivet is the leading scotch in this market, then you can see that, yes, it is growing and – with premiumization.

Perrier-Jouët, plus 9%, that's a very good achievement. I mean, it's a – value churn is also – I mean the U.S. is the top market in value for the brand and we have a favorable mix and price impact. Kahlúa, I mean, too early to say that we have achieved a turnaround, but the brand is stabilizing, and we have a pipeline of innovation.

Brazil, strong growth and globally, plus 13%, and an impressive number for the Top 14, plus 26%, and this is driven by Absolut and the Scotch whiskies. But I mentioned to you that we introduced Passport, plus 24%. We have also this local vodka, plus 9%, and this is very much brands targeting the middle class.

Canada, plus 7%, and this is due to mainly Jameson and Malibu and a good performance of the wine. And the wine are very profitable in this market. That's the – due to the monopoly situation, since we have good margin with the wine.

Mexico, yes, that's the country where we suffer. But you know that this is, in fact, mainly driven by us. We are setting up a new business model for Mexico with a clear intention that the focus shall be from now onward the premium brand, the top 14, and not any more the local brands. So, Mexico, this is the sort of cleaning-up of the market and the implementation of this new business model.

And strong performance in other markets and I was – from my holidays in Colombia and in Peru, I met the team and I can tell you they're enthusiastic and it's – particularly for Peru. The team was set up just a year ago. You can't imagine more Pernod Ricard-minded people than those guys. I mean, it's a good reflection of the way we manage our business.

Europe, excluding France, so clearly, bipolarizations. So the – which one, the East and the West, the top 14 is the main growth driver and this is Jameson, Chivas, Beefeater, I would mention that, I mean, Beefeater in Spain performed very well, but also The Glenlivet and Absolut. We suffered with Ballantine's in Spain. I mean, that's clearly the case, and this was also for Havana Club in Spain and in Italy.

The Priority Premium Wines, those had the slight decline, minus 2%, but this is at the benefit of the value and the profit. We will see the numbers; Alexandre will show it to you soon. The key local brands, plus 6%, and this is particularly mainly due to Russia, Seagram's Gin and Becherovka.

Looking at geography, so the bipolarization, Eastern Europe acceleration, I mean, plus 16%. We're plus 9% the previous year. Russia, main growth driver, plus 28%, the Top 14 at plus 31%, Jameson, Chivas, Ballantine's and, of course, local brand, ArArAt and Olmeca.

The launch of Passport. So, again, introducing this brand targeting the middle class and we're very confident that Passport will be a fantastic brand, I mean, fantastic tool for capturing this middle class. Ukraine, plus 25%, Poland, minus 6%, but this is the local Polish vodka. On the contrary, Ballantine's double-digit growth. And I remind you that we are the leader in the premium – standard premium Scotch with Ballantine's.

Western Europe, modest decline, minus 1%. Of course, it reflects difficult situation. Spain, minus 4%, Italy, minus 13%, the same for Greece, UK, slightly negative, minus 4%. On the contrary, Germany, plus 5%, The Netherlands, plus 7% and Belgium, plus 2%. So, at the end of the day, we can say that, yes, the Southern Europe remained the black spot and probably will remain so for the coming year, because we didn't see any sign that the economy should recover soon.

And France, well, in average, our brands suffer a 14% duty hike. We told – I went visiting the ministers and say, "This is a far too high duty increase. You won't get the money you expect because that will impact the volumes." And unfortunately, I was right. But they make the decision.

So, we had a very high first half, and of course, the contraction in the second half, but what is reflecting the market is definitely the Nielsen. Since January, so since the duty increase is reflected on the shelf, so, overall the spirit market is in the range of minus 2%. The Nielsen for the anis, what is more impacted by the duty hike, is in the range of minus 6%. With our brand, we saw it behaving – I mean, absolutely in line with the markets, and so it's more at the expense, by the way, of the private label.

So, the consumption decline is just reflecting, of course, the overall economic climate, but definitely this duty hike. And so, nonetheless, we had good performance with Absolut at plus 13% and Havana Club at plus 13% as well. So, there are still some pocket of growth which we can capture and reflect them in the motivations and the enthusiasm of our sales people. I think that's very much what about I wanted to tell you about in the development of our sales.
And now, Alexandre will enter into the brands, that means our beautiful brands. So, Alexandre?

Thank you very much, Pierre. So, from a brand point of view, one key message, our overall net sales, organic growth has clearly been driven by our 14 spirit and champagne brands, growing at double digit in line with last year at 10%. And they now represent 60% of our total net sales. Second, our premium lines are now growing by 4% versus 0% last year. And this is clearly the result and the benefit of our high-value strategy, which I'll slightly touch upon later. And our 18 key local brands have accelerated their growth pace, and we'll see it's been driven by local Indian whiskies, Passport, ArArAt, Olmeca. I'll touch upon this later. While the key message here, volume, 3%; sales up 10%. Two-thirds of the growth is driven by the price mix impact, a perfect value creation lever.

If we dwell into our Top 14 brands, I'd say, number one, the key message here is we have reached an all-time record volume for our Top 14 brands, reaching a first milestone of many obviously, I hope, of 50 million cases, exactly it's 47.2 million. This is actually – we have 8 out of the 14 brands which have posted historical high volume. We also have six brands in double-digit growth. And finally, overall comment, the dynamism of our portfolio here is clearly driven, number one, by Martell; and number two, by our portfolio of whiskies.

Now, brand by brand, to start with Absolut, volume and net sales growth in line at 3%, growing across all regions. Specific focus on the U.S., Pierre mentioned it earlier, an improved trend in the second half. And actually, NABCA, for the last three months, is up between 5% and 6%. The on-trade depletions are now in positive growth and, as well, the latest Nielsen panels that you've probably seen, are in growth as well.

Strong growth as well in Brazil. Actually, Brazil is up 26%. In Africa and Middle East, double digit as well. Germany, South Korea, Russia, France, as Pierre mentioned, up 13% despite the depressed environment, India and Thailand. Just to mention the short-term negative impact due to number one, a change in distributor in Israel and number two, as Pierre mentioned it, the change – the voluntary change of our business model and the reengineering of our business in Mexico. And let's just mention that if we had to extract these two countries, Absolut would post a 5% growth.

Moving now into Chivas, well, it's a record year for Chivas as well in terms of volume. Net sales are up 11%, growth driven a little bit by all key regions: Asia/Rest of the World, up 16%; Eastern Europe, up a staggering 22%; and South America, mainly Brazil, up 10%. The depletions have turned positive now in the U.S., up 2%, with a positive mix effect. Very strong growth in travel retail, up 19%, and premiumization clearly underway, where you see the higher qualities, be it Chivas 18, up 28% or Chivas 25, up 28% as well.

Ballantine's, stable. Stable because as Pierre mentioned it, a sharp decline in Spain. And the entire Scotch category is very depressed in Spain, but the growth on the higher qualities and Duty Free mainly and in Asia. Strong development of Ballantine's as a brand in Eastern Europe, with 51% growth of net sales in Russia, 11% growth in a very promising market for the scotch category, which is Poland; 42% growth in Ukraine; and in Latin America, Brazil posted a 19% growth for Ballantine's.

Ricard, no need to dwell upon it. Pierre mentioned it, the duty hike in January 1 and as well, an unfavorable weather impact. Jameson net sales, global net sales up 18%. Outstanding performance in line with that of previous years, driven by, again, the U.S., its number one market, up 29%, and Russia, which – where net sales grew 45% and which is now the number two market for Jameson, just ahead of South Africa, where the brand grew as well.

I just want to mention as well, because it's going to be posted today, Jameson has been nominated as the number two IWSR Elite Brand of the year. So, which one was number one IWSR Elite Brand of the year, well, Havana Club.

So, Havana Club in its core historical markets has suffered, that being Spain, Italy and Cuba. In Spain in Q3, in May, June of the last fiscal, we launched Ritual, Ritual by Havana Club, to basically go at the conquest of the dark rum segment in Spain. There's ongoing very strong momentum in Germany for the brand, net sales up 13%, in line with Nielsen panels, and it remains the brand's main market in value terms. And, as well as mentioned earlier, very strong development in France despite the environment, up 13%; Nielsen panels actually up 20. The brand is very active in the on-trade segment in France as well. Very good growth in Russia, up 20%.

Well, Malibu, I would only stress the fact that Malibu is the perfect example of how innovation can completely reinvigorate a brand. Malibu net sales are up 4%. A lot of new initiatives over the last year, the Malibu Cocktails, Malibu Black and the most latest launch, which was Malibu Red in collaboration with Ne-Yo, one of the famous pop star in the U.S. in Q3. I would qualify this as a stretched innovation, crossing two different categories, which is rum on one side and tequila on the other. And therefore as a result, the performance of Malibu in the U.S. is just excellent, up 10%. The brand is also posting solid growth in Germany, up 9%, in Canada, in Russia as well, and sustained growth, albeit from a small base, but growing very high double-digit numbers across all Asia. And Malibu as well has reached its record high.

Likewise for Beefeater in terms of record level of volumes, Beefeater net sales are up 7%. Outstanding growth in Europe, up 8%, with an excellent performance in Spain, up 6%. It is the direct result of a very extremely powerful campaign, the Forever London campaign. Improvement of the performance as well in the U.S., another key market for the brand, and rapid development in Russia and Africa and Middle East. I'd like to stress that there is a feeling amongst our teams that there is a rejuvenation of the gin category as a whole, and Beefeater will play a significant part in that.

Kahlúa. Well, Kahlúa on a global level is stable. We do have very encouraging results of the new brand positioning, which is Rum & Coffee Liqueur. There are numerous upcoming innovations for Kahlúa. There is a repack under way, which will soon be on the shelf. And I would like to underline the strong performance of Kahlúa in Canada and strong development as well of Kahlúa in Russia, up 41%.

Well, regarding our prestige brands, up 25%, 19%, 6%, 14%, 23%. Basically8 an extremely good year to start with, with Martell, a remarkable year driven by Chinese Asia and across all Asia. The strongest favorable price mix impact for the entire portfolio of Pernod Ricard, up16% from a price mix point of view, with as well a good quality mix: XO up 39% in terms of net sales and Noblige up 29%; very successful launch of Chanteloup Perspective. Strong development as well outside of Asia, in Russia, up 10%; and in Africa and Middle East, which is a promising continent which we are conquering as of recently, up 23%.

The Glenlivet, the malt that started it all, very strong performance in its key historical and mature markets: up 9% in the U.S.; 33% in Taiwan; 11% in the UK; and 52% growth in travel retail. And very strong performance as well in other key markets in Asia, including, by the way, India, as we mentioned it earlier.

Mumm and champagne, we've had a very good year from a champagne point of view. If we look at Mumm, up 1% in France; up 11% in Spain despite the environment; up 1% in Italy; increased momentum in China, up 51%, which has now become our number two market for Mumm, behind France; and continued growth in the U.S., up 26%.

Well, outstanding performance as well for Perrier-Jouët, globally up 14%; coming from its three key markets, the U.S. of 9%, especially on the high qualities such as Belle Epoque; Japan, up 15%, Pierre mentioned it, and France, up 16%. Sales have doubled in China which is now the number three export market for the brand. So, basically, the message here is for our champagne portfolio, China is now becoming a very important market. While our most prestigious scotch whisky, Royal Salute, up 23% with its unique brand positioning, a Scotch whisky which starts where everybody else ends and double-digit growth basically across (31:59) and in Travel Retail.

For Priority Premium Wines, well, the three numbers you see here, 2%, 4% and 10%, are a direct result of our high-value strategy, driven both by price, price increases or promotional activities driven by cost optimization. And, therefore, if you look at brand by brand, Jacob's Creek volume is down 1%, sales up 2%. The brand suffered in the UK as a result of the strategy, where Jacob's Creek's net sales are down 10%. Brancott Estate, volumes up 5%, sales up 2%. Campo Viejo, volume, 9%, net sales, 11%. In the UK, by the way, net sales for Campo Viejo up 6%. And Graffigna, basically in America, volume is up 3% and sales up 28%.

Regarding our 18 key local brands, key message here is accelerated growth, number one, driven by our Indian local whiskies, Royal Stag, Blender's Pride, and Imperial Blue. We're reaching the 0.25 billion liters of sales in India, driven as well by the conquest of the emerging middle class elsewhere. Passport up 22%, Brazil, Mexico, but as well, other markets including Africa, recently launched as well in Russia. Driven as well by ArArAt, very strong growth driven by Russia, but as well, all of Eastern Europe, Ukraine, et cetera, (33:36) up 26%, Olmeca up 20% and Something Special up 15%. And again, as Pierre mentioned, difficult year for Imperial due to the shift from traditional to modern, which is benefiting on our Top 14 brands in Korea and 100 Pipers, which posted a 4% decline in Thailand.

I'll just very briefly drift through some initiatives. We do invest close to €1.6 billion very wisely behind our brands. Regarding Absolut, it's all about connecting with the artistic community. I will underline the – I think most of you saw it, the Greyhound advertising campaign which started in the U.S. and became viral on a global basis, more than 20 million online viewers for the Drinks 2.0 initiatives.

Beefeater, well, it's all about capturing the energy and the contemporary and vibrant London, with Beefeater 24, by the way, growing close to 50% still from a very small base, but Beefeater is really being reinvigorated. Havana Club, it's all about capturing the values and the culture of Havana, so a very strong year in terms of activation about authentic rum and mojitos.

While Jameson, it's all about word of mouth, which is working – which is connecting with passionate people about the brand and advocates. A partnership as well signed with Kevin Spacey, more than 5.5 million views on YouTube.

Regarding wines, well, it's all about, again, differentiation and premiumization of our wines, connecting with the emotional side of our consumers. And I would strongly suggest you go on the Internet and see what Andre Agassi has to say about Jacob's Creek. But likewise, pretty differentiation campaigns about Campo Viejo across the world, especially in the UK and Graffigna in America.

Well, we're clearly now targeting the high-net-worth individuals across the world, more than 12 million of them and growing, and aspirational consumers by creating a world of luxury, essentially around our high-end cognac Martell brands, our high-end Royal Salute brands and around our high-end champagnes, creating unique experiences that go beyond just price as a differentiation factor.

Finally, innovation, which is a key pillar of our strategy alongside premiumization and geo expansion. Well, Pierre mentioned earlier about Café de Paris in terms of flavors, new flavors, and in terms of tapping into new aperitif trends with, for instance, the Bitter Orange Spritz. New flavors as well and SKUs for Soho, for instance, or Suze, which is back on growth in France, its core market.

And last but not the least, tapping into, as well, or going at the conquest of new consumer – consumption occasions. For instance, the on-the-go coffee occasion with the Kahlúa Cans, party-time occasions with Ritual for the time being in Spain and girls' night together with – on the picture, you see Naomi Watts, with Jacob's Creek Cool Harvest. Gilles?

Thank you, Pierre. Thank you, Alexandre. I propose now to share with you a bit more figures, starting with the overview of the P&L. As Pierre said, our best financial performance since the last 2008 crisis, with sales up organically 8%. It was 7% last year. So, this is an acceleration, with an increase in the operating margin rates by 75 basis points, largely driven by premiumization and some control over resources, A&P and structure cost; and an operating profit from recurring operations growing by 9%. It was 8% last year. It was above the 8% guidance, so very solid growth.

It was largely driven by the organic growth. As you can see, the operating profit from recurring operations was up 11%, 9% coming from organic growth. We also had some positive impact from the ForEx, which turned positive in Q4, thanks to a stronger U.S. dollar and RMB. We plan, obviously, this positive ForEx to go on in fiscal year 2012-2013.

Gross margin, after logistic costs, a strong improvement in the rates, 111 basis points up, driven by the portfolio mix. As you saw before, the growth in top 14 sales, 10%, was higher than the group growth, 8%. And within that portfolio, brand by brand, we had a particular favorable quality mix for Martell, for Jameson, among other brands. We have managed to increase our prices. On average, the top 14 prices were up 3%. At the same time, we've been able to control the inflation of the input costs. They were up 2%, excluding the different mix effects. And we also benefited from a favorable ForEx impact.

A&P, as we can see, they were up organically 7%. The ratio was slightly up. Obviously, as I said before, Top 14 growth was higher than the average of the group. As you know, they receive more A&P than the other brands. The ratio, A&P to net sales is a bit above 24%, three-fourth of the total A&P expenditure. We have allocated this A&P to other priority markets. In emerging markets, A&P were up 11%. On the other hand, in Western Europe, we have optimized our investments. A&P was down 2%.

Structure cost, the ratio was almost stable. We had an 8% increase, which is in line with the organic sales growth. As for the A&P, we put our resources where it makes sense. So, we have increased our resources in emerging markets. They represent 63% of the gross. I mean, structural costs in emerging markets grew by 16%. In particular, that's the case in the BRIC. In China, it was up 31%. In India, it was up 27%, in Russia, 22%. This is clearly more people in our sales force, more people to strengthen our route to market. And at the same time, also to the companies, the development of the group in new areas of growth, we have created subsidiaries in Vietnam and Sub-Saharan Africa.

In Western Europe, as for the A&P, we have also optimized our structures and the increase in structure costs was lower than inflation. And those additional resources were also in line with our strategic priorities. And we have put more money behind innovation. In particular, we launched recently a Breakthrough Innovation Group, and more money also behind our people in talent management. And we also launched during the year the Pernod Ricard University.

As a consequence of all that, profit from recurring operations was up organically 9%. This is a significant increase in the operating margin, up 75 basis points, thanks to premiumization, which has improved the gross margin.

Control over resources, as you saw, the A&P expenditures ratio was slightly up and they are focused on our most profitable brands. And we have also targeted the reinforcement of the sales force of the most buoyant countries, in particular, the BRIC. We also benefited from a favorable ForEx.

So, if we have a look at this profit performance by region, as you can see, except for France, for the reason you know, the excise duty hike, all regions contributed to organic growth in profit, in particular, Asia, which confirmed its continued very strong momentum, and with some acceleration in the United States, which obviously have to improve the performance in the Americas and in Eastern Europe.

Starting with Asia/Rest of the World, so I would not comment on the activity that you saw previously with Pierre. What we can say that, well, sales up 15%; profit up 21%, very strong growth, strong increase in gross margin, which continues to benefit a lot from our improved mix and improved price. And some targeted investment to support brands. We benefit obviously from the scale of large men in the region (43:07) region like Martell. And we have the ability to invest more behind new growth drivers which are sources obviously of diversification of our growth in the region. And also as I said before, more money behind the sales force to put more people on the road to sell our brands in China, Africa, India, in particular. And as a consequence, we had a substantial improvement in the operating margin rate from 25.2% to 27.8%.

Americas, we have put more money in that region. In A&P, it was up 5%; in structure costs, largely driven by the sales force evolution, up 9%. As you know, this is a priority region for the group. We want to grow. We want to put more resources to be able to increase our market share.

The growth was driven by the U.S. and Brazil, which are the two priority markets in the region. And the third one, Mexico, as you know, we commented that last year, was penalized by the fact – from a financial standpoint, by the fact that we implemented the new strategic model, which obviously hope will deliver growth starting now. And as the operating margin rate was stable in that region, it makes sense, it's origin where we want to increase our investments.

So, let's have a look at what is below the operating profit, starting with the financial reserves from recurring operations. It was up from 4.7% to 5.1%, that said, below the target we had communicated to you, which was 5.3%.

So, if we have a look at the different elements of that strategy, first of all, we have increased the share of the bond debt to more than 80%. We believe that today, we have a healthy balance of bank and bond debt, which makes sense in the current environment. Obviously, the spreads were a bit higher than the previous bank debt, and so, it created an increase in the cost of debt.

We have also increased the fixed-rate part to a bit more than 90% to be able to secure very attractive long-term rates, and it gives us, obviously, a very good protection against the potential of increasing rates in the future. We have increased the maturity to more than seven years. And those maturities are extended, and they are better spreads. We have a better profile of our debt. We have €1.5 billion of undrawn facility, obviously, giving us additional financial flexibility. And in terms of hedging, we have not changed our policy. We still have our debt structured by currency to try to match our cash flow by currency, so what we call the natural hedge, so we have 57% of the debt which is in dollars.

Cash flow statement, we delivered, I think, again a solid free cash flow from recurring operations, more than €1.1 billion, marginally lower than last year while, at the same time, substantially increasing strategic investments.

We had a significant increase in the self-financing capacity, as you saw on the previous slide. It was up €194 million, largely driven by the growth in the profit, operating profit. And it was reinvested behind our strategic assets to support the future growth. So, I would like to highlight, on the one hand, the acceleration of growth of strategic inventories. They were up €157 million as compared to €85 million last year, in particular in cognac, whiskies and champagne.

And we have also increased our capital expenditure, in particular, the industrial one by €77 million. It now reaches €260 million in total. We have increased the distillation and storage capacities in Ireland. We have a big project to increase the decision capacity for Jameson Scotland, France and Sweden. So, this is clearly investment to be able to fuel the very high growth we have and we plan for our strategic activities. The cash flow from non-recurring items was more or less stable versus last year.

So, what we have here is the change in net debt. Net debt was down €385 million, excluding the translation impact. If you adjust for acquisition and disposals of last year and the year before, it's very comparable to the definition we had the year before.

On the other hand, the face value of the debt was up, because of an unfavorable ForEx impact of €710 million, obviously, and I think these are things we have very – constantly commented in the last two years with the strings of currencies. This year, the price of euro-dollar at the end of June was far – the euro was far lower than at the beginning of the year. It was $1.26 as compared to $1.45. And so, you had the direct impact on the debt.
Obviously, the positive counterpart for us is the positive ForEx impact on EBIT. We had part of it last year. We have the largest portion of this positive ForEx impact in 2012/2013.

Deleveraging. Another strong year for deleveraging. As a ratio net-debt-to-EBITDA, the average rate was down from 4.4 to 3.8, down 0.6. We are now below 4. By the way, it will improve the spread of the syndicated credit by 15 basis points in 2012/2013.

On the right hand side, we have summarized the evolution of this ratio in the last four years. Income tax from recurring operations, the rate is 23.5%. It is exactly in the middle of the bracket we had communicated to you earlier this year. We had announced a bracket of 23%, 24%. Very quickly, non-recurring items, we had some negative other operating income expenses of €145 million, including restructuring cost, some asset impairment, in particular, in the wine business and some cost for disputes and risks.

So, the group share of net profit after recurring and non-recurring items is up 10% as for the group share of net profit from recurring operations.

The proposed dividend is €1.58 per share, increase by 10%. It is in line with our customary policy of cash distribution of approximately one-third of net profit from recurring operations. The distribution rate is near from 35%.
